bibl.title: Letter from George Parker to Henry Rose Carter, March 16, 1923

div1.p: Parker describes his malaria education efforts.

div1.head: Letter from George Parker to Henry Rose Carter, March 16, 1923
div1.opener:
N. M. C.
Parker
W.W. HALL, M.D. PRES., SHELBY, MISS.
J.M. McNEILL, M.D., OLIVE BEACH, MISS.
B. LAMPTON CRAWFORD, M.D., TEMPLETOWN, MISS.
T.F. ELAIN, M.D., TUSSELS, MISS.
H.F. GARRISON, M.D., CLINTON, MISS.
L.L. McDOUGAL, M.D., BOONEVILLE, MISS.
MISSISSIPPI STATE BOARD OF HEALTH
T.W. REAGAN, M.D., UNION, MISS.
C.D. MITCHELL, M.D., JACKSON, MISS.
I.L. PARSONS, M.D., , MISS.
E.M. GAVIN, M.D., OVETT, MISS.
W.H. WATSON, M.D., BRANDON, MISS.
J.M. WINDHAM, M.D., ECRU, MISS.
Mississippi State Board of Health
W.S. LEATHERS, M.D., EXECUTIVE OFFICER
JACKSON, MISS.
BUREAU OF SANITARY ENGINEERING
----
H. A. KROEZE, C. E.,
State Sanitary Engineer
Yazoo City, Miss.,
March 16, 1923.
Dr. H. R. Carter,
Asst. Surgeon General, USPHS,
2121 California St.,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
Your letter contained some information that
is of value to me;-the information of where malaria faver had
its origin, so to speak.

What I meant to convey in the bulletin was
that we could not say whether the patient or the mosquito was
the first to get the parasite.

My plan in getting out a monthly bulletin is
to give to the people in this county, as near as possible in
their own language, correct information relative to the malaria
situation and its control possibilities. In doing this I make an
effort to construct the bulletins so they will make interesting
reading matter to induce the reading of them. For the county I
have a mailing list of nearly 1000, so selected as to reach all
classes. This list is being increased from time to time.

What do you think of the idea, and do you
consider the bulletins so constructed as to get the maximum result?

I am now organizing a county-wide mosquito
extermination association and hope before long to have county-wide
control measures in operation directed by the people themselves
with the local health department cooperating or acting in an advis-
ory capicity. It is hoped to have this association eventually lead
into all classes of health work and put Yazoo County in an area
free from all preventable diseases.

I have two offers to go to Texas; one on general
sanitary work and the other on mosquito elimination problems.

We are always glad to hear from you, and hope
you will not overlook us with any interesting information.
